Topic.Title: Alibaba Gets to Legally Manipulate Yahoo's Stock. It's All Good in the End.

Message.Msg: LMAO none of what you said is even realistic! The buyout disappeared long ago and left for DEAD as the stock has risen from the teens. Their core is worse than ever...search is gone, display market share is down 66% to 7%, in a matter of years. Short covering??? Its NON-EXISTANT and if not for day traders or swing traders or institutions HEDGING it'd be ZERO. For a squeeze of any sort you'd need the shares short to number 20-30-40%, Yahoo is under 3% I believe. No one is going to pay $30B MORE for an increase in mobile users when the companies revenue is still under $5B, down from its $6.5B from 07'. They could have a TRILLION users but means NOTHING if they can't monetize it and so far they haven't been able to monetize anything in the last 6yrs. A back of a napkin calculation: YJ- $9B so $6B after-taxes Cash- $5B AG-let's say $20B or $13B left Core- say $10B or twice revenue $34B/1.08 shares=$31.48...maybe they elude taxes(doubtful) but I don't think the core is worth $10B either, I'm just not a hype sort of guy. Glad you're optimistic just not realistic.

Topic.Title: Alibaba Gets to Legally Manipulate Yahoo's Stock. It's All Good in the End.

Message.Msg: Out of 1.08 BILLION shares it ain't #$%$ and as I said its likely a HEDGE to long positions, its been at those levels for YEARS or are you telling me that companies out there have ZERO shares shorted? 29M out of 1.08B shares is 2.5%. So in a normal 20M trading day...19,500,000 are LONG shares. They could cover at their leisure all year and not move the needle. To get ANY action, you need a heavily shorted stock in the 30-40% short range. Want an example of shorts getting taken to the woodshed look at Tesla where it was 40% short and the stock tripled as they scrambled to cover since May? Gannett(GCI) was heavily shorted and I rode it from $2/$3 to $6 and eventually $10+. Solars were heavily shorted in the past year and some have doubled or tripled in the past few weeks but they too had short shares in the 30-40% range. Yahoo will never have a "short squeeze" cause I don't expect them to buy up 1B+ shares outstanding to make it even possible.

Message.Title: 2nd Quarter and 9 months results
Message.Msg: Yahoo! Reports Second Quarter 2013 Results SUNNYVALE, Calif.--(BUSINESS WIRE)-- Yahoo! Inc. (YHOO) today reported results for the quarter ended June 30, 2013. Q2 2012 Q2 2013 Percent Change GAAP revenue $1,218 million $1,135 million (7)% Revenue ex-TAC $1,081 million $1,071 million (1)% GAAP income from operations $55 million $137 million 150% Non-GAAP income from operations $240 million $209 million (13)% GAAP net earnings per diluted share $0.18 $0.30 68% Non-GAAP net earnings per diluted share $0.30 $0.35 19% “I'm encouraged by Yahoo!’s performance in the second quarter. Our business saw continued stability, and we launched more products than ever before, introducing a significant new product almost every week,” said Yahoo! CEO Marissa Mayer. “From the new Yahoo! News, the new Yahoo! Sports app, the redesigned Yahoo! search, the new Flickr, the new Yahoo! Mail for tablet, the Yahoo! Weather app, our new Yahoo! app with Summly - this quarter drove tremendous improvements in our product line and our users responded with increased usage and engagement.” GAAP revenue was $1,135 million for the second quarter of 2013, a 7 percent decrease from the second quarter of 2012. Revenue excluding traffic acquisition costs (“revenue ex-TAC”) was $1,071 million for the second quarter of 2013, a 1 percent decrease compared to the second quarter of 2012. Adjusted EBITDA for the second quarter of 2013 was $369 million, a 7 percent decrease compared to the same period of 2012. GAAP income from operations was $137 million for the second quarter of 2013, a 150 percent increase from the second quarter of 2012 (which reflected a restructuring charge of $129 million).

Message.Msg: You don't need the story its one of the teen slides in the Powerpoint presentation found every quarter on their Investor Relations website. Its honestly the only bright spot I seen in the whole presentation. A year ago, $5B in revenue seemed to be the floor and now they're forecasting for 4.5B down from 4.8B. If you're forecasting down per SEC rules, to err on the side of caution, how can they say "growth in the 2nd half"? As for AG, that makes $2.6B in net income for the year, but 24% indirectly turns into $624M and $400M after-tax which means by next year Yahoo will earn LESS than its investments perhaps by far...crazy!
